revised_title: Polymerization of N-Carboxy-α-amino Acid Anhydrides: Kinetics and Mechanism
tldr: The authors studied the polymerization of N-carboxy-α-amino acid anhydrides, focusing on the leucine, phenylalanine, and sarcosine derivatives. They found that the first two anhydrides polymerize at rates dependent on monomer and initiator concentrations, while the sarcosine derivative has a different reaction rate. The authors propose a reaction scheme involving the formation of a complex between the monomer and a base, followed by decomposition with the evolution of carbon dioxide. This mechanism explains the observed kinetics and the role of catalysts in the polymerization process.
